reviewText:
I shall be one of the lame people who does an actual serious review for this game because.. Why not?

I'll start off by issuing a warning that if you have epilepsy, take all games seriously or you just can't handle pixelated nudity then steer very clear of this, it's not for you.

Developed and published by Marbenx, let's take a look at Shower with your Dad Simulator 2015.

Gameplay: As difficult as it is to write about; Shower With Your Dad Simulator 2015 is a series of actually challenging mini-games(e.g Endurodad, Dadathon, Dad Divisions, Soapia etc.), topped with pixely nudity, all kinds of dads and a rather addicting streak to it.

Menu: Extremely simplistic, but done in a decent way. The only thing that I dislike is that if you hit escape, the game will close on you.

Soundtrack: Each mini-game has it's own soundtrack that is looped in a pretty non-annoying way even after a decent amount of play time, and it's actually good!

Final Conclusion: I found myself getting frustrated time and again over the curve-balls it will sometimes throw you. Something as tiny as a puddle on the floor will have you slide into the wrong dad and make you start over, or lose your streak(depending on which mode you're in). It's a nice challenge that by no means takes itself seriously and I think that's what I enjoy most about it.

It keeps you trying that one more time to beat your previous score, that is the sign of a well put together game for entertainment.

In all, I recommend it if you like simplistic yet fairly difficult games to keep you on your toes. Also if you like Showering with Dad simulators, nudity, showers and pixely goodness.

reviewText:
“Shower with your dad simulator 2015” is a indie 2D Scrub-em-up time trial game. You play as 1 of three kids trying to make his way over to his dad, avoiding puddles, wet floor signs, and other, not so friendly dads.




The game is separated into 7 game types, each more ridiculous as the last. Some game modes are locked and unlocked over time, by playing the basic modes. The 2 basic modes, are similar, the first one, you pick your kid and have to race to your dad to add more time, as well as get more points. The second gamemode, you are assigned a random kid, and have to get to that kids, dad, thus adding time, and adding points.



As 2D the game is, it holds its own, graphically speaking. Everything that appears, like obstacles or powerup, are all very clear to the player. The rubber duck looks like a rubber duck, and the wet floor sign looks like a wet floor sign. The music in the game is a mix of fantastic and annoying. The main menu music is clearly stock music from somewhere, but the ingame music is a great loop that oddly doesn't get annoying.




Shower with your dad simulator 2015 does a lot right:



It doesn't take itself serious


It has many game modes so it doesn't get boring


It’s comical, in later game modes


It’s price is extremely low


Its achievements are easy




Shower with your dad simulator 2015 does some things wrong:



Distracting wangs


No real game to be played


Lacks any sort of story


not that much fun after an hour or so



Overall, Shower with your dad simulator 2015 is a good game. Boring at times, but easy to get into, and easy to 100%. well worth the $1.09CAD.

reviewText:
I think everyone has played at least one game that tried way too hard to be funny. For me, that's something like McPixel or Retro City Rampage. Shower With Your Dad Simulator 2015: Do You Still Shower With Your Dad is the opposite of that, a game so earnest about its uncomfortable, almost-homoerotic premise that you can't help but like it. The game commits to it as hard as it can, focusing all 6+ of its modes entirely around showering with your dad. And remarkably, beneath the polished madness of its presentation, is a solid and often surprising game.

SWYDS2015:DYSSWYD is a collection of minigames, each like a fleshed-out WarioWare microgame. You start with three unlocked, and can unlock the rest by playing the game, though the means by which you unlock them are mysterious and delightful on their own. The first mode, Endurodad, has you playing one of three children in a timed search for his depurating (yes I used a thesaurus for that) father. Controlling the tot with just the arrow keys, you run him right into his dad to earn extra time and build your Dadstreak. If you hit the wrong dad, showertime ends. Every time you tag the right dad, the assorted bathers and obstacles are re-randomized, making it a hectic dash back and forth through the shower room. There are wet floor signs that slow you, puddles that send you skidding away, and more and more dads to confuse you as you go. The second mode, Dadathlon, is similar, except every time you find the right dad you switch to a different kid, and each individual search is timed. Finding the wrong dad only gives you less time on the next search. Both modes have very steady difficulty curves that you can overcome with time. There are also power-ups to unlock such as soap, beer, and rubber duckies, but I would be lying if I said I understood what most of them did. They certainly spice up the gameplay, which is enough for me.

The third mode, Dad Divisions, is a pretty big departure. Instead of freely scooting around the showers, your child is stuck running left and right, catching falling showering dads. Mouse click extends his naked arm in bionic fashion to snatch dads from the air, and the up arrow changes what kid you are so you can match them to the right dad. It feels like an intense puzzle game and makes a nice break from the other two modes. There are more modes beyond these but I'll not spoil them for you, for their discovery is a major reason to play the game at all. I will say that while they offer dramatically different gameplay, they have certain flaws that the base three modes do not suffer from. Still, their discovery and variety add a lot to the overall package. On top of all that, there are some microgames that randomly pop up in between rounds that can range from quicktime events to... stranger things.

As a game, Shower With Your Dad Simulator 2015 is a dense package to explore that will easily last you a few hours if you let it. The presentation only adds to the charm, being a weird cross between 8-bit homage and Hotline Miami visual weirdness. Every game starts with a dad joke, and the low-res genitalia cannot and will not be censored (seriously, try it in the options). For the price you absolutely cannot go wrong, because this is the rarest of games, the one that is built around a single joke and makes it work.

reviewText:
Shower With Your Dad Simulator is mainly different minigames revolving around a kid and his dad showering. Sometimes, when reloading a level, you have a minigame to play.

Endurodad is the first mode you can try. In it, you choose your pair between three fathers and their kids. Your goal is to reach your dad before the time's out. But if you're showering with the wrong one, it's the end of the round too! Many powerups can appear on the screen: a beer, while not perfect to see, is at least slowing time, the adventure map changes your dad during a limited time, another one is making you have two dads (which means less chance to end up wrong). The more you're scoring, the more complicated it will be: dads being curtains, dads being added, signs slowing you, puddles making you slide, etc..

Dadathlon is based on the same mechanics than Eurodad, apart that you're not choosing your dad: each time, the kid is changing, so it's up to you to find the right one.

Dad Divisions is a mode where the dads are falling down. You need to get them before they touch the ground. But to make sure you don't take the wrong one, you'll have to change the kid.

Soapico is a point-&-click adventure (not taking long) where your dad is an investigator and is trying to find what happened.

The Dad With the Iron Shower is a mode where you need to avoid three ninjas kids and any object thrown at you by the Ninja Daddy.

Inglorious Bathdads is a mode where the kid is in a flying tube and has to touch the tube where his dad is. You can also gun down the others.

That's the content of the game. In reality, the fun comes because you're challenged, either by the achievements or by trying to beat your score.

But it's the humor in it and the fact that it's a parody of a simulator that makes the game very enjoyable. The powerups are not quite recommended for kids - I think about the beer for example. I also appreciated the two dads option, because it's making the job easier and also because of the symbolism of it being included.

The graphics are in the wave of retro gaming: it's pixelised and it's probably a way to avoid criticism about sex as the kids and the dads are naked. So, yeah, there is the equipement between the legs being pictured.

The soundtrack is also good. It's a joy to hear it during your games.

So yeah, Shower With Your Dad Simulator may be cheap but the fun provided in it is real. You make a real bargain here. Don't hesitate at all!

reviewText:
Shower with Your Dad Simulator 2015 is a game about matching three different colored children to their corresponding fathers in the shower... the end. Truth be told I'm still at a loss as to what in the world I just played. This game features multiple game modes to play including Endurodad, Dad Divisions and Inglorious Bathdads. As you can no doubt figured out by the title of this game alone, it is very weird and likely the type of game gifted to you by friends that secretly hate you. In a strange turn of events leaving the shock factor aside it is actually kind of fun. You will start off with three modes unlocked while the rest will be available after spending time simply playing the game. Endurodad allows you to select which son you play as and tasks you with repeatedly going to his location but touch a man that's not your dad and its game over.

Dadathlon is very similar but a much more exciting as you have to reach dad in a very short time and after touching him you will randomly change to a different colored kid which forces you to stay on your toes. The more you play the more useless items you'll unlock that will randomly spawn around the shower such as a razor to trim all their hair and a rubber duck that gives your dad floaties even though he is standing in a shower. The only controls for this is the arrow keys which you use to move around and are not able to be rebinded. There is nothing of use in the options menu as they are all joke settings like an FOV slider as well as a nudity toggle that in reality can't be switched off. If you thought showering with your dad is as weird as it gets you’re sadly mistaken since this games developers are more than likely insane.

After playing those two modes enough a tub may randomly spawn and touching it sends you into the Matrix or something only to be thrown out into the clouds piloting a floating bath tub. Your goal here is to shot down the other dads and collect 69 dads of your color. It plays a bit like Flappy Bird in that you have to be constantly pressing the button as you will automatically descend as gravity takes its toll unless you thrust yourself upwards. Shooting the other dads down doesn't really have any benefits other than clearing a path for you if in a tight spot. Another mode called Dad Divisions will have your kid be tasked with grabbing his falling dad by extending his freakishly stretchy arms. The controls for this mode are really awkward since you will be moving with the arrow keys as well has needing to aim for your dad using the mouse so unless you are left handed this setup is very clunky.

Soapico mode plays like an adventure game in that you'll need to collect items and put them together to solve environmental puzzles. There are even more modes to choose from which gives this title a surprising amount of content especially considering it is priced at a dollar. Playing these I feel like I'm playing rather decent Atari 2600 games once you manage to look past how insanely weird the presentation of it is. Funnily enough this does run at 60 fps and the only real criticisms I have of it are the lack of rebinding and being unable to pause the game. Even the music is rather decent although the loops are way too short. It does get boring very fast however so I'm not saying you should go out and buy this but if you are gifted this by someone or want to weird people on your friends list out it is surprisingly more than a throw away YouTube bait title.

reviewText:
Shower With Your Dad Simulator 2015 is a spectacular AAA title with gameplay that is reminiscent to XCOM and Dark Souls, with unforgiving difficulty that keeps you coming back for more!

The eye-popping graphics and unique art style sucks the player into its immersive story-driven world. I really felt like I was showering with my dad!

The soundtrack score was simply breathtaking, like something out of Game of Thrones or Skyrim. You're going to want a proper Hi-Fi to fully appreciate the complexity of the soundtrack, preferably a pair of 120ohm Yamaha speakers with an appropriate amplifier.

In conclusion, I am shocked this game didn't win any Game of the Year awards, as I was far more involved with this game than Fallout 4 or The Witcher 3.

reviewText:
My first exposure to this title was watching the trailer several months ago. While it managed to emit a moderate amount of laughter & proceeded into the obvious conversation referencing the ominous tide of terrible simulator games now available on Steam, I thought little more of it.

Seeing it out for sale at the quite frankly ludicrous price of £0.79, I figured that 5 minutes of humour for the price of a half a chest key on TF2 wasn't such a crazy proposition. That predicted 5 minutes turned into a huge under estimate!

Rather than a poorly coded unity engine game as most simulators seem to be, this is more akin to a ZX Spectrum or C64 type pixel game as alluded too in its fake crack screen opening. The gameplay, excluding the titular humour is possibly one of the most addictive things I've played since the Three's phone game 2 years or so ago.

At first glance it will seem like a simple arrow key control, timer based match game. The progression however is somewhere between the Binding Of Isaac (with unlockable item drop progression increasing your potential score) & Frog Fractions. The latter so much so that there's even a homage to that game as an extra mode.

As well as the three starting modes there's also several more hidden variations wildly different from the original match game all based around the theme of dads while riffing on some of the sillier aspects of gaming.

For £0.79 you'd be crazy not to play this game as it's definitely something you'd want to compete score wise against with friends. What could have easily been a one joke riff on a silly title, actually ended up being a rather brilliant game! Much more than supposedly legit games with 'simulator' strapped on the title screen for 10-20x the price.
